case_name: The Mill v. Poona Girni Kamagar Union

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 323 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 323 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated July 2, 1953 in Special Civil Application No. 159 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 2, 1953 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 159 of 1953.

facts.text: Bombay High Court granted certificate of fitness on July 20, 1954 under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: On July 20, 1954, the High Court of Judicature at Bombay granted a certificate of fitness under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution that the judgment of that companyrt dated July 2, 1953, passed in Special Civil Application No. 159 of 1953, was a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court as it involved a substantial question of law,

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company owning Cotton Textile Spinning and Weaving Mill in Poona employing large number of workmen with a union.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant which may hereafter, for the purpose of companyvenience, be called The Mill, is a limited companypany owning and possessing a Cotton Textile Spinning and Weaving Mill situated in Poona, employing a large number of workmen who have a union of theirs.

facts.text: First respondent is a workman employed by the Mill and member of second respondent Poona Girni Kamagar Union.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent is a workman employed by the Mill and the second respondent is the Poona Girni Kamagar Union of which the first respondent is a member.

facts.text: Appellant running 580 looms with one weaver allotted two looms.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was running 580 looms, for working which one weaver had been allotted at the rate of two looms and when things were in that state

facts.text: On August 29, 1951, Management issued notice for experiment of four looms per weaver from September 1, 1951 for 2 months on 16 looms.

anchor.surface_text: on August 29, 1951, the Management issued a numberice to the effect that from September 1, 1951, it was desired to carry on an experiment of four looms to a weaver for a period of 2 months, on 16 looms.

facts.text: Object of notice was to introduce rationalization or efficiency system if experiment successful.

anchor.surface_text: If at the end of that period or before the expiry of the same it was found that the working was successful, the Management would introduce the scheme after giving the numberice of change required under the Act. The object of this numberice was ostensibly to introduce rationalization or rather efficiency system of work,

facts.text: On September 4, 1951, Secretary of the Union wrote to Manager objecting to change without notice under Bombay Industrial Relations Act.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this numberice on September 4, 1951, the Secretary of the Union wrote to the Manager of the appellant Mill intimating that under the Bombay Industrial Relations Act the Management companyld number legally introduce any change in the existing system ,of working without first giving numberice of the change in the prescribed form to the representatives of the Union and workers

facts.text: Four workers volunteered and started experimental work on 16 looms on September 6, 1951, but other workmen objected and prevented them.

anchor.surface_text: Four workers volunteered to work the experiment and started working accordingly on the 16 looms on September 6, 1951, whereupon the other workmen raised an objection and the four loyal workmen were prevented from companytinuing with the experimental work.

facts.text: Management did not withdraw notice and required others except the 4 to take part in experiment.

anchor.surface_text: - But the Management did number withdraw the numberice and numbere except the 4, was required by the Management to take part in the experiment.

facts.text: Second shift refused to work resulting in complete strike from September 6 to 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The second shift among the workmen also refused to work with the result that there was a companyplete strike in the Mills between the 6th and the 26th of September, 1951.

facts.text: On September 10, 1951, appellant filed application under sections 78 and 97 of Bombay Industrial Relations Act to declare strike illegal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1951 the appellant filed an application under sections 78 and 97 of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946  Bom. XI of 1947 , praying that the strike resorted to by the weavers working on both the shifts companymencing on September 6, 1951,

facts.text: On September 16, 1951, Vice-President of Mill Mazdoor Sabha filed written statement denying illegal strike, claiming refusal only of illegal work.

anchor.surface_text: On September 16, 1951 the Vice-President of the Mill Mazdoor Sabha filed a written statement in answer to the above company- plaint stating that the workers did number strike work in companytravention of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act and that the weavers never refused to do their proper and usual work but refused only to do the illegal work insisted on them by the employers

facts.text: Two workers filed application under sections 78 and 98 before Labour Court against Management for illegal lockout and to withdraw illegal change.

anchor.surface_text: Within three days of the filing of the above written statement, two of the workers filed an application under sections 78 and 98 of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act before the same Labour Court against the Management praying for a declaration that the action of the Management had resulted in an illegal lockout

facts.text: Labour Court by combined order dated September 26, 1951 held no illegal lockout, no illegal strike, but illegal change and ordered withdrawal of notice.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court at Bombay heard both the applications together and by a companybined order dated September 26, 1951, held that since the Management had number companypelled any one to accept any work, their action companyld number be-considered an illegal lockout. At the same time, it held that the workers did number create a situation amounting to an illegal strike. ... declared that the action of the Management was an illegal change and, therefore, the numberice whereby the experiment was attempted to be tried, should be withdrawn.

facts.text: Management appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Appeal No. 293 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the Management having been aggrieved by the declaration that their action amounted to an illegal change filed an appeal before the Labour Appellate Tribunal at Bombay  Appeal No. 293 of 1951

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held strike illegal, no lockout, set aside illegal change declaration.

anchor.surface_text: upon which the learned Judges of the Labour Appellate Tribunal took the view that the strike by the workmen was illegal. They also companycluded that there was numberlockout on the part of the Management. That being the case, the order of the Labour Court declaring that there was an illegal change was set aside with the declaration that the strike in question was illegal

facts.text: Two workers filed application for writ of certiorari in Bombay High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 against LAT order.

anchor.surface_text: In order to get the said order of the Labour Appellate Tribunal quashed, an application for a writ of certiorari under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution was filed by the two of the workers before the High Court of Bombay

facts.text: Bombay High Court (Chagla C.J. and Dixit J.) quashed LAT order, upheld Labour Court, judgment dated July 2, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: where Chagla C.J. and Dixit J., took the view that since the decision of the Appellate Tribunal was erroneous, the same should be quashed, with the result that the decision of the Labour Court was upheld. It is this judgment that is under appeal before us

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by GOVINDA MENON J. on October 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. October 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GOVINDA MENON J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held strike illegal under s.97(1)(c) as commenced and continued only for reason that employer made illegal change.

anchor.surface_text: The action of the workmen, therefore, came within the express terms of s. 97 1   c  of the Act. ... We are, therefore, of the opinion that, on a proper interpretation of s. 97 1   c  of the -Act, the strike which was companymenced and companytinued from September 6, to September 26, 1951, was clearly illegal.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside, Labour Appellate Tribunal order restored declaring strike illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the order of the High Court dated July 2, 1953, is set aside. The result, therefore, is that the order of the Labour Appellate Court dated September 4, 1952, stands, with the declaration that the strike in question was illegal

facts.text: Workers in application claimed Management action resulted in illegal lockout and illegal change.

anchor.surface_text: In their application to the Labour Court, they said That for the above-mentioned reasons it is prayed that this Honourable Court be pleased to declare the said lockout by the opponent Mills as illegal being in company- travention of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, and the opponent be ordered to withdraw the said illegal change.

facts.text: Strike from September 6 to September 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: there was a companyplete strike in the Mills between the 6th and the 26th of September, 1951.

issues.text: Whether a strike is illegal under s.97(1)(c) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act if commenced or continued only for the reason that the employer has made an illegal change, irrespective of whether the change was actually illegal

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has pressed two arguments before us with regard to the construction of s. 97 1 c of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act., 1946. His first argument is that the High Court was in error when it held that there was any such right as a common law right of an employee to go on strike

issues.text: Whether there is a common law right of employees to go on strike such that s.97(1)(c) constitutes an inroad only prohibiting strikes for illegal changes but implying prohibition for legal changes as well

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel has submitted that under s. 97 f c a strike shall be illegal if it is commenced or continued only for the reason that the employer has not carried out the provisions of any standing order or has made an illegal change if a strike is illegal when it is commenced or continued only for the reason that the employer has made an illegal change, a fortiori it must be illegal

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that Mr. Gokhale is right in his contention, it is clear to us that if the workmen commence or continue a strike for the only reason that the employer has made an illegal change, they come within the express terms of s. 97 1 c . It is immaterial whether the change is subsequently found by the Labour Court to be a legal change.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetically assuming right to strike for collective bargaining, s.97(1)(c) still applies if reason is perceived illegal change

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the order of the High Court dated July 2, 1953, is set aside. The result, therefore, is that the order of the Labour Appellate Court dated September 4, 1952, stands, with the declaration that the strike in question was illegal with its usual companysequences.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it is unnecessary to decide in this case whether the first argument of learned counsel for the appellant is correct or not because we are clearly of the opinion that the second argument with regard to the construction of s. 97 1 c is correct and should prevail In this case the workmen themselves came to court with the plea that the action of the employer amounted to an illegal change.

The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the order of the High Court dated July 2, 1953, is set aside. The result, therefore, is that the order of the Labour Appellate Court dated September 4, 1952, stands, with the declaration that the strike in question was illegal with its usual companysequences.

anchor.surface_text: The action of the workmen, therefore, came within the express terms of s. 97 1   c  of the Act. ... We are, therefore, of the opinion that, on a proper interpretation of s. 97 1   c  of the -Act, the strike which was commenced and continued from September 6, to September 26, 1951, was clearly illegal.

The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the order of the High Court dated July 2, 1953, is set aside. The result, therefore, is that the order of the Labour Appellate Court dated September 4, 1952, stands, with the declaration that the strike in question was illegal with its usual companysequences.
